{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2012}} {{Infobox spaceflight | name = Kwangmyŏngsŏng-3 Unit 2 | image = | image_caption = North Korean leader Kim Jong-un inspects Kwangmyongsong-3 Unit 2 days before launch | mission_type = [[Earth observation]]
[[Weather satellite|Meteorology]]
Technology | operator = [[Korean Committee of Space Technology|KCST]] | COSPAR_ID = 2012-072A | SATCAT = 39026 | mission_duration = 2 years (planned) | spacecraft_bus = | manufacturer = [[Institute of Military Electronics]] | dry_mass = {{convert|100|kg|lb|0}}{{cite web|title=Status of North Korean Satellite unknown after prolonged Radio Silence, Reports of Tumbling|url=http://spaceflight101.com/status-of-north-korean-satellite-unknown-after-prolonged-radio-silence-reports-of-tumbling/|website=Spaceflight101}} | launch_mass = | power = | launch_date = {{start-date|12 December 2012, 00:49|timezone=yes}} UTC | launch_rocket = [[Unha|Unha-3]] | launch_site = [[Sohae Satellite Launching Station|Sohae]] | launch_contractor = | disposal_type = | deactivated = | last_contact = | decay_date = | orbit_epoch = 14 December 2012{{cite web |url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/satcat.txt |title=Satellite Catalog |publisher=Jonathan's Space Page |first=Jonathan |last=McDowell |accessdate=3 May 2018}} | orbit_reference = [[geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[Low Earth orbit|Low Earth]] | orbit_periapsis = {{convert|498|km|mi}} | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|581|km|mi}} | orbit_inclination = 97.41 degrees | orbit_semimajor = {{convert|6921|km|mi}} | orbit_eccentricity = 0.0065 | orbit_period = 95.43 minutes | apsis = gee }} {{wikinews|North Korea successfully launches long range rocket}} '''Kwangmyŏngsŏng-3 Unit 2''' or '''Gwangmyeongseong-3 ho 2-hogi''' ({{korean|hangul=《광명성―3》호 2호기{{cite web|url=http://www.naenara.com.kp/ko/news/news_view.php?0+47525|title=조선우주공간기술위원회 대변인 대답|publisher=Naenara|accessdate=12 December 2012}}|hanja=光明星3號2號機|mr=Kwangmyŏngsŏng-3 ho 2-hogi|rr=Gwangmyeongseong-3 ho 2-hogi|context=north}}; English: Bright Star-3 Unit 2 or Lodestar-3 Unit 2) is the first [[satellite]] successfully launched from [[North Korea]], an Earth observation spacecraft that was launched on 12 December 2012, 00:49 [[UTC]], in order to replace the original [[Kwangmyŏngsŏng-3]], which failed to reach orbit on 13 April 2012.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-20690338|title=North Korea defies warnings to launch rocket|publisher=BBC|date=12 December 2012|accessdate=12 December 2012}} The [[United Nations]] [[United Nations Security Council|Security Council]] [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 2087|condemned]] the satellite launch, regarding it as a violation of the ban on North Korean ballistic missile tests, as the rocket technology is the same.{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-15278612 | work=BBC News | title=North Korea profile | date=26 March 2014}} The launch came during the period when the [[DPRK]] was commemorating the first anniversary of the death of former leader [[Kim Jong-il]] and just before the first [[South Korea]]n domestic launch of a satellite and the [[South Korean presidential election, 2012|South Korean presidential election]] on 19 December 2012. The successful launch makes the DPRK the tenth [[Timeline of first orbital launches by country|space power]] capable of putting satellites in orbit using its own launch vehicles. North Korea declared the launch successful, and the South Korean military and [[North American Aerospace Defense Command]] (NORAD) reported that initial indications suggested that an object had achieved orbit.{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/50167891/ns/technology_and_science-space/|title=North Korea reports successful launch of controversial rocket|publisher=MSN/NBC}}{{cite web|url=http://www.norad.mil/News/2012/121112b.html |title=NORAD acknowledges missile launch |publisher=North American Aerospace Defense Command |date=11 December 2012 |accessdate=12 December 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121214134546/http://www.norad.mil/News/2012/121112b.html |archivedate=14 December 2012 |df= }} North Korea had previously claimed the [[Kwangmyŏngsŏng-1]] and [[Kwangmyŏngsŏng-2]] launches as successful,{{cite web|last=Encyclopedia Astronautica|title=1998.08.31 - Kwangmyŏngsŏng 1|url=http://www.astronautix.com/details/kwa11163.htm|accessdate=15 December 2012}}{{cite news|title=N.Korea says it successfully launched satellite|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2009/04/05/idUKSEO88417|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=15 December 2012|date=5 April 2009}} despite American military sources claiming that they failed to achieve orbit.{{cite web|last=United States Northern Command|title=NORAD and USNORTHCOM monitor North Korean launch|url=http://www.northcom.mil/News/2009/040509.html|accessdate=15 December 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121017015121/http://www.northcom.mil/News/2009/040509.html|archivedate=17 October 2012|df=dmy-all}}{{cite news|title=North Korea space launch 'fails'|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/7984254.stm|publisher=BBC|accessdate=15 December 2012|date=5 April 2009}} Several days after the launch, Western sources stated that, while the satellite had indeed initially achieved orbit, it now seemed to be tumbling, and was probably out of control.{{cite news|last=Talmadge |first=Eric |title=Crippled NKorean probe could orbit for years |url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/crippled-nkorean-probe-could-orbit-years?goback=.gde_3433693_member_197139555 |accessdate=2012-12-18 |newspaper=AP |date=2012-12-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029210856/http://bigstory.ap.org/article/crippled-nkorean-probe-could-orbit-years?goback=.gde_3433693_member_197139555 |archivedate=29 October 2013 |df= }} ==Etymology== The name "Kwangmyŏngsŏng" is richly symbolic for [[North Korean nationalism]] and the [[Kim family cult]]. While Soviet records recount that the late North Korean leader [[Kim Jong-il]] was born in the village of [[Vyatskoye, Khabarovsk Krai|Vyatskoye]] near [[Khabarovsk]] in the [[Russian Far East]],{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/1907197.stm |title=Profile: Kim Jong-il |publisher=BBC News |date=16 January 2009 |accessdate=28 December 2011}} [[DPRK]] internal sources claim that Kim was born on [[Mount Baekdu]] and that on that day a bright [[Celestial navigation|lodestar]] ("kwangmyŏngsŏng") appeared in the sky.{{cite news|url=http://www.worldministries.org/prophecynewsarticles/korea_north/120414_US_stops_food_aid_North_Korea_after_rocket_explodes_nkorea.html|title=US stops food aid to North Korea after rocket explodes|last=Wen|first=Philip|date=14 April 2012|work=Sydney Morning Herald|accessdate=13 December 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130410082751/http://www.worldministries.org/prophecynewsarticles/korea_north/120414_US_stops_food_aid_North_Korea_after_rocket_explodes_nkorea.html|archivedate=10 April 2013|df=dmy-all}} ==Background== The launch of Kwangmyŏngsŏng-3 Unit 2 was the fourth North Korean attempt to orbit a satellite, and North Korea claimed that two of the previous launches had placed their payloads into orbit despite several other countries confirming that the launches had failed, and no independent confirmation that the satellite was in orbit.{{cite web|url=http://www.astronautix.com/details/kwa11163.htm|title=1998.08.31 - Kwangmyŏngsŏng 1|first=Mark|last=Wade|work=Encyclopedia Astronautica}} The first attempt occurred in August 1998, with a [[Paektusan (rocket)|Baekdusan]] carrier rocket attempting to launch [[Kwangmyŏngsŏng-1]]; the second occurred in April 2009 with [[Kwangmyŏngsŏng-2]], and the third in April 2012 with the original [[Kwangmyŏngsŏng-3]]. The April 2012 launch was the only one which North Korea acknowledged to have failed. However, the launch of Kwangmyongsong 3 Unit 2 made North Korea the tenth country to place a satellite into orbit using an indigenously developed carrier rocket.{{cite news|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/2012/12/12/277669/north-koreas-successfully-launches-satellite/|title=North Korea successfully launches satellite|date=12 December 2012|publisher=PressTV|accessdate=13 December 2012}} The rocket was largely made using domestically produced parts and technology; this ability is seen as cause for greater concern over North Korea's ability to develop ballistic missile technology despite sanctions.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-21115985|title=North Korea rocket was domestically made|publisher=BBC News|date=21 January 2013|accessdate=23 January 2013}} ==Pre-launch announcement== The launch was announced on 1 December 2012, when the [[Korean Central News Agency]] reported that the Korean Committee of Space Technology informed them that they "[plan] to launch another working satellite, second version of Kwangmyŏngsŏng-3, manufactured by its own efforts and with its own technology, true to the behests of leader Kim Jong-il," with a prospective launch window of 10–22 December 2012 given. The launcher splashdown zones were reported to the [[International Maritime Organization]], indicating a [[polar orbit]] was intended.{{cite web |url=http://allthingsnuclear.org/north-korea-gives-location-of-splashdown-zones-begins-assembling-rocket/ |title=North Korea Gives Location of Splashdown Zones, Begins Assembling Rocket |author=David Wright |publisher=Union of Concerned Scientists |date=4 December 2012 |accessdate=12 December 2012}} On 8 December 2012, KCNA reported that the [[Korean Committee of Space Technology|KCST]] answered the "question raised by KCNA, as regards the launch of the second version of Kwangmyŏngsŏng-3 satellite" and also reported that the launch period was extended to 29 December 2012. ==Satellite== North Korea claims the satellite would estimate crop yields and collect weather data as well as assess the country's forest coverage and natural resources. The country also claims that the satellite weighed about 100 kg (220 lbs) and that its planned lifetime was about two years.{{cite web |author=AdminGMT |url=http://nknews.org/2012/03/n-korea-reveals-details-of-kwangmyŏngsŏng-3-satellite/ |title="N. Korea Reveals Details of Kwangmyŏngsŏng-3 Satellite", NK News, 29 March 2012 |publisher=Nknews.org |date=29 March 2012 |accessdate=13 April 2012 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ==Launch== [[File:Kwangymyongsong-3-2 gt.jpg|thumb|right|Satellite [[ground track]] of Kwangmyŏngsŏng-3 Unit 2, 14 December 2012]] On 12 December 2012, Kwangmyŏngsŏng-3 was launched from the [[Sohae Satellite Launching Station|Sohae Satellite Launching Ground]] at 00:49:46 UTC (09:49 KST).{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/north-korea-launches-long-range-missile/story?id=17939423|title=US Calls North Korea Rocket Launch a 'Provocative Act'|last=Riviera|first=Gloria|author2=Joohee Cho |author3=Akiko Fujita |date=12 December 2012|publisher=ABC News|accessdate=13 December 2012}} The North American Aerospace Defense Command was able to track the rocket at this time. The first stage impacted the ocean {{convert|200|km}} off the west coast of South Korea at 00:58, with the fairing coming down one minute later {{convert|100|km}} downrange. At 01:01, the rocket flew over Okinawa, with the second stage impacting {{convert|300|km}} east of the Philippines four minutes later.{{cite news|url=http://globalnation.inquirer.net/59451/north-korea-rocket-parts-plunge-east-of-luzon|title=North Korea rocket parts plunge east of Luzon|last=Aning|first=Jerome|author2=Nikko Dizon |date=13 December 2012|work=Philippine Daily Inquirer|accessdate=13 December 2012}} During the ascent the rocket performed a dog-leg manoeuvre to increase its inclination sufficiently to attain sun-synchronous orbit. The satellite was deployed into a [[sun-synchronous orbit|sun-synchronous polar orbit]] with an [[apsis|apogee]] of {{convert|584|km}}, a [[apsis|perigee]] of {{convert|499|km}}, 97.4 degrees of [[orbital inclination]], and an [[orbital period]] of 95 minutes and 29 seconds.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/worldviews/wp/2012/12/12/how-did-north-korea-fix-its-rocket-program-so-quickly/|title=How did North Korea fix its rocket program so quickly?|last=Fisher|first=Max|date=12 December 2012|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=13 December 2012}} The spacecraft separated from the rocket's third stage at 00:59:13; nine minutes and 27 seconds after liftoff. The [[United States Space Command|U.S. Space Command]] began to track three objects from the launch, giving Kwangmyŏngsŏng-3 the [[Satellite Catalog Number]] 39026 and the [[international designator]] 2012-072A.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/american-space-expert-says-satellite-launch-a-perfect-success-for-north-korea/2012/12/11/4237283e-4411-11e2-8c8f-fbebf7ccab4e_story.html|title=American space expert says satellite launch a 'perfect success for North Korea'|date=11 December 2012|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=13 December 2012}} {{Dead link|date=April 2014|bot=RjwilmsiBot}} They later began tracking a fourth object that was related to the launch. The following day, U.S. officials tracking the satellite reported that it appeared to be "tumbling out of control" in its orbit.[http://worldnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2012/12/12/15866530-north-korean-satellite-tumbling-out-of-control-us-officials-say?lite North Korean satellite 'tumbling out of control'] – NBCNews.com, 12 December 2012. However South Korean sources said that the satellite was orbiting normally.{{cite news|title=North Korean satellite 'orbiting normally' after rocket launch|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/dec/13/north-korea-satellite-rocket-launch|newspaper=The Guardian|date=13 December 2012|location=London}} Data collected by Spain, Italy and Britain suggest the brightness of the satellite has been fluctuating, which indicates it is tumbling as it orbits.{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2012/12/18/astronomers-say-apparently-malfunctioning-north-korea-satellite-could-orbit/|title=Astronomers say apparently malfunctioning North Korea satellite could orbit Earth for years|publisher=AP Tokyo/Fox News|date=18 Dec 2012|accessdate=23 January 2013 }} ===Examination=== South Korean missile experts examined components of the missile from the two stages of the rocket that fell back to Earth. Initially they reported the components were of poor quality and some foreign made. Further examination revealed that most of the components were produced domestically in North Korea. They were effective for the launch, but found mostly to be crude, unreliable, and inefficient. The rocket design was based on older technologies of the 1960s and 70s. The design of the rocket engine was almost identical to one built in Iran.[http://www.strategypage.com/htmw/htspace/20130131.aspx We Did It Ourselves] – Strategypage.com, 31 January 2013 ==Reaction== At noon local time, the [[Korean Central News Agency]] released a news report on the launch: {{Quotation |Pyongyang, December 12 (KCNA) -- The second version of satellite Kwangmyŏngsŏng-3 successfully lifted off from the Sohae Space Center in Cholsan County, North Phyongan Province by carrier rocket Unha-3 on Wednesday. The satellite entered its preset orbit.|KCNA }} The report was followed by a more detailed report later in the afternoon stating: {{Quotation |Scientists and technicians of the DPRK successfully launched the second version of satellite Kwangmyŏngsŏng-3 into its orbit by carrier rocket Unha-3, true to the last instructions of leader Kim Jong Il. Carrier rocket Unha-3 with the second version of satellite Kwangmyŏngsŏng-3 atop blasted off from the Sohae Space Center in Cholsan County, North Phyongan Province at 09:49:46 on December 12, Juche 101(2012). The satellite entered its preset orbit at 09:59:13, 9 minutes and 27 seconds after the lift-off. The satellite is going round the polar orbit at 499.7 km perigee altitude and 584.18 km apogee altitude at the angle of inclination of 97.4 degrees. Its cycle is 95 minutes and 29 seconds. The scientific and technological satellite is fitted with survey and communications devices essential for the observation of the earth. The successful launch of the satellite is a proud fruition of the Workers' Party of Korea's policy of attaching importance to the science and technology. It is also an event of great turn in developing the country's science, technology and economy by fully exercising the independent right to use space for peaceful purposes. At a time when great yearnings and reverence for Kim Jong Il pervade the whole country, its scientists and technicians brilliantly carried out his behests to launch a scientific and technological satellite in 2012, the year marking the 100th birth anniversary of President Kim Il Sung.|KCNA }} On 20 December, the Korean Central Television aired a 27-minute documentary titled "Successful Launch of Kwangmyongsong 3-2 under the Leadership of Dear Respected Marshal Kim Jong-Un". The documentary showed footage of the preparations for the rocket launch and how Kim Jong-Un was involved in the preparations.{{cite web|title=North Korean TV Airs "New" Rocket Footage|url=http://www.nknews.org/2012/12/north-korean-tv-airs-new-rocket-footage/|publisher=NK News|accessdate=23 December 2012}} ===Internal celebrations=== Government vans with loudspeakers brought the news of the launch of Kwangmyŏngsŏng-3 to Pyongyang soon after the launch.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-20691021 |title=N Koreans speak of 'pride' over banned rocket launch |publisher=BBC |date=12 December 2012 |accessdate=12 December 2012}}{{cite news|title=North Korea Rocket Launch: Celebrations In Pyonyang|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/12/12/north-korea-rocket-launch-celebrations_n_2283776.html|work=news article|publisher=Huffington Post, Associated Press|accessdate=13 December 2012|date=12 December 2012}} On 14 December state television in North Korea broadcast images of hundreds of thousands of people celebrating the successful launch in Pyongyang's central square, while military and scientific personnel gave speeches. According to the news report, [[Kim Jong-Un]] had ordered more satellite launches after achieving orbit with Kwangmyŏngsŏng-3.{{cite web|title=North Korea celebrates rocket launch|url=http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/1720653/North-Korea-celebrates-rocket-launch|publisher=SBS News Australia|accessdate=14 December 2012}} According to a report from Radio Free Asia, following the launch, the KCNA alerted people to watch a "Special News" announcement. Afterward people throughout the country were pulled from work and school to participate in mass celebrations. Those in [[Sinuiju]], [[Pyongan]] were forced to dance in freezing weather to celebrate North Korea's success.{{cite news|title=North Koreans Sour on Launch|url=http://www.rfa.org/english/news/korea/launch-12182012182455.html|first=Joshua|last=Lipes|date=18 Dec 2012|work=[[Radio Free Asia]]|accessdate=30 January 2013}} ===International response=== ====Countries==== * {{flag|Australia}} – Prime minister [[Julia Gillard]] labelled the launch as a "provocative and irresponsible act", and a violation of United Nations Security Council resolutions.2012-12-12, [http://www.smh.com.au/opinion/political-news/gillard-slams-north-korea-rocket-launch-20121212-2b9gv.html Gillard slams North Korea rocket launch], The Sydney Morning Herald * {{flag|Brazil}} – The [[Ministry of External Relations (Brazil)|Itamaraty]] issued a statement condemning the rocket launch and called for North Korea to "comply in full with the applicable resolutions of the U.N. Security Council" and asked for the resuming of negotiations "on peace and security in the Korean Peninsula".{{cite web|url=http://www.itamaraty.gov.br/sala-de-imprensa/notas-a-imprensa/lancamento-de-foguete-pela-coreia-do-norte|title=Lançamento de Foguete pela Coreia do Norte|publisher=Ministry of External Relations of Brazil|date=12 December 2012|accessdate=16 December 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130115051542/http://www.itamaraty.gov.br/sala-de-imprensa/notas-a-imprensa/lancamento-de-foguete-pela-coreia-do-norte|archivedate=15 January 2013|df=dmy-all}} * {{BUL}} – The [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Bulgaria)|Foreign ministry]] described the launch as "a clear violation of the international obligations of the DPRK" and urged North Korea to refrain from further actions that could lead to the "isolation of the country".{{cite web|url=http://www.mfa.bg/en/events/6/1/597/index.html|title=Concerning today's long-range missile launch by the DPRK|publisher=Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Bulgaria|date=12 December 2012|accessdate=12 December 2012}} * {{flag|Canada}} – Canada condemned the missile launch, and Foreign Affairs Minister [[John Baird (Canadian politician)|John Baird]] stated that North Korea's actions "clearly demonstrate its wilful defiance of its international obligations". He also added that the regime has shown disregard for its people by funding military and nuclear programs before providing basic necessities for its citizens.{{cite web|title=Canada condemns North Korea's 'wilful defiance' after rocket launch|url=http://news.nationalpost.com/2012/12/12/canada-condemns-north-koreas-wilful-defiance-after-rocket-launch/|work=National Post|date=12 December 2012|accessdate=12 December 2012}} * {{flag|China}} – The [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the People's Republic of China|Foreign ministry]] expressed concerns and "hope[d] parties concerned can take a long-term perspective, deal with this calmly and appropriately, avoid taking actions that may further escalate the situation, and jointly maintain the peace and stability on the Korean Peninsula and in the region as a whole."{{cite news|title=DPRK succeeds in satellite launch, draws protests|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/world/2012-12/12/c_132036294.htm|agency=Xinhua News Agency|date=12 December 2012|accessdate=12 December 2012}} * {{flag|Colombia}} – Colombia, in consonance with the United Nations Security Council, being a non-permanent member on the time of the launch, and having ratified the [[Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons]], condemns the launch of the rocket Unha-3 executed by the [[DPRK]] via a press release from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Colombia also noted that "the DPRK breaches the resolution 1718 of 2006 as well as 1874 of 2009," and urges it to comply with the resolutions, adding that "such act affects the stability in the Korean Peninsula as well as international peace and security."{{cite news|title=COMUNICADO DE PRENSA SOBRE EL LANZAMIENTO DEL COHETE REALIZADO POR LA REPÚBLICA POPULAR DEMOCRÁTICA DE COREA (RPDC)|url=http://cancilleria.gov.co/news/news/node/4377|agency=Ministerio de Relaciones Exteriores Republica de Colombia|date=12 December 2012|accessdate=15 December 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130119220446/http://www.cancilleria.gov.co/news/news/node/4377|archivedate=19 January 2013|df=dmy-all}} * {{flag|Hungary}} – The [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Hungary)|Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] is deeply concerned about the implemented rocket launch. The launching is a clear violation of the country's international obligations and UN Security Council Resolution 1718 and 1874. Hungary calls upon the DPRK to abide by its international obligations especially as it is defined by the relevant UN Security Council Resolutions. Hungary also urges the DPRK to refrain from any destabilising actions that could further increase tensions in the region.{{cite news|title=Hungary Condemns DPRK's Rocket Launch|url=http://www.kormany.hu/en/ministry-of-foreign-affairs/news/hungary-condemns-dprk-s-rocket-launch|agency=Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Hungary|date=12 December 2012|accessdate=15 December 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130218153432/http://www.kormany.hu/en/ministry-of-foreign-affairs/news/hungary-condemns-dprk-s-rocket-launch|archivedate=18 February 2013|df=dmy-all}} * {{flag|India}} – India's [[Ministry of External Affairs (India)|Ministry of External Affairs]] condemned the launch, saying it was concerned that 'unwarranted action' by North Korea would impact the stability of the whole peninsula, and noting that it was a violation of U.N. Security Council Resolution 1874.{{cite web|title=India joins in condemning North Korea's rocket launch|url=http://www.rediff.com/news/report/india-joins-in-condemning-north-korea-s-rocket-launch/20121212.htm|publisher=Rediff News|date=12 December 2012|accessdate=12 December 2012}} * {{flag|Iran}} – General Masoud Jazaeri, a senior military official, congratulated North Korea on the launch, saying that "experience has shown that independent countries, by self-confidence and perseverance, can quickly reach the height of self-sufficiency in science and technology. Hegemonic powers, such as the United States, are unable to stop the progress of such countries."{{cite news|title=N. Korea's launch sparks worries about nukes, Iran and the Pacific|url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/12/12/world/asia/north-korea-rocket-launch/index.html?hpt=hp_c1|publisher=CNN|date=12 December 2012|accessdate=12 December 2012}} * {{flag|Japan}} – Government spokesman [[Osamu Fujimura]] condemned the launch, saying that "it is extremely regrettable that North Korea went through with the launch despite our calls to exercise restraint. Our country cannot tolerate this. We strongly protest to North Korea."{{cite news|title=North Korea rocket: International reaction|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-20690762|publisher=BBC|date=12 December 2012|accessdate=12 December 2012}} * {{flag|Philippines}} – The [[Department of Foreign Affairs (Philippines)|Department of Foreign Affairs]] condemned the launch, stating that the decision was in "clear violation" of three UN Security Council resolutions which "explicitly demanded the country not to use or conduct any launch using ballistic missile technology and the suspension of its ballistic missile program."{{cite web | url=http://globalnation.inquirer.net/59367/ph-condemns-north-koreas-rocket-launch-dfa | title=PH condemns North Korea's rocket launch—DFA |publisher= [[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]| date=12 December 2012 | accessdate=15 December 2012}} * {{flag|Romania}} – The [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Romania)|Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] strongly condemned the launch, stating that North Korea "blatantly encroached upon the UN Security Council resolutions" and adding that "Romania, throughout its mandate of Local Representation of the EU in Pyongyang in the second half of 2012, has repeatedly conveyed messages to the DPRK authorities [...] demanding that Pyongyang refrain from any action affecting peace and security in North-East Asia."{{cite web | url=http://www.mae.ro/en/node/17137 | title=MFA press release on launch by the DPRK of a satellite using ballistic missile technology | date=12 December 2012 | accessdate=15 December 2012}} * {{flag|Russian Federation}} – The [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Russia)|Foreign ministry]] released a statement stating "The new rocket launch carried out by North Korea [flouts] the opinion of the international community, including calls from the Russian side, and leaves us with deep regret."{{cite news|title=Russia voices 'deep regret' over North Korea rocket launch|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/12/12/us-korea-north-russia-launch-idUSBRE8BB09N20121212|agency=Reuters|date=12 December 2012|accessdate=12 December 2012}} [[Russian Defense Ministry]] said its early missile warning systems had tracked the rocket launch along a southern trajectory, the [[Interfax]]-AVN military [[news agency]] reported.[https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/12/12/us-korea-north-russia-launch-idUSBRE8BB09N20121212 "Russia voices "deep regret" over North Korea rocket launch"] * {{flag|South Korea}} – [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (South Korea)|Foreign Minister]] [[Kim Sung-hwan (diplomat)|Kim Sung-hwan]] strongly denounced the launch, saying that "North Korea ignored repeated warnings and demands by the international community" and that "it should bear grave responsibility for the launch as the U.N. Security Council warned with its presidential statement in April." The [[Republic of Korea Navy]] later salvaged debris from the rocket, and a South Korean senior military official said, based on the debris, that the design of the oxidizer tank suggested an "Iran connection".{{cite news |title=North Korean Missile Said to Have Military Purpose |author=Choe Sang-Hun |url=http://mobile.nytimes.com/2012/12/24/world/asia/north-korean-rocket-had-military-purpose-seoul-says.xml |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130216141851/http://mobile.nytimes.com/2012/12/24/world/asia/north-korean-rocket-had-military-purpose-seoul-says.xml |dead-url=yes |archive-date=16 February 2013 |newspaper=New York Times |date=24 December 2012 |accessdate=15 January 2013 }} * {{flag|Taiwan}} – Via a spokesperson, President [[Ma Ying-jeou]] expressed that "the two North Korean rocket tests of this year have caused an uneasy situation in East Asia", and that he believed that such actions were unwise. It was also announced that Taiwan supported the international community in its opposition to North Korea's actions.{{cite news|title=北韓發射火箭　馬英九總統：不智！|url=http://www.nownews.com/2012/12/12/91-2881650.htm|accessdate=12 December 2012|newspaper=NOW News|date=12 December 2012}} * {{flag|United Kingdom}} – Foreign Secretary [[William Hague]] stated that he "deplore[d] the fact that the DPRK has chosen to prioritise this launch over improving the livelihood of its people".{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/dec/12/north-korea-rocket-launch-condemnation|title=North Korea rocket launch provokes widespread condemnation|work=The Guardian|first=Tania|last=Branigan|date=12 December 2012|accessdate=12 December 2012|location=London}} * {{flag|United States of America}} – A spokesman for the [[United States National Security Council|National Security Council]] described the launch as "another example of North Korea's pattern of irresponsible behavior"{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/theoval/2012/12/12/obama-north-korea-missile-launch-tommy-vietor/1762927/|title=U.S. condemns North Korea missile launch|first=David|last=Jackson|work=USA Today|date=12 December 2012|accessdate=12 December 2012}} and called for "a clear message to North Korea that its violations of U.N. Security Council resolutions have consequences." * {{flag|Vietnam}} – Foreign Ministry's Spokesperson Luong Thanh Nghi stressed " We expect relevant parties will not take actions harmful to the region's peace and stability and strictly observe the [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 1874]]".{{cite web|url=http://news.gov.vn/Home/VN-raises-concern-over-DPRKs-coming-satellite-lauch/201212/16474.vgp |title=VGP News | VN raises concern over DPRK's coming satellite {{sic|lauch|hide=y}} |publisher=News.gov.vn |accessdate=2012-12-17 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130402232947/http://news.gov.vn/Home/VN-raises-concern-over-DPRKs-coming-satellite-lauch/201212/16474.vgp |archivedate= 2 April 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }} ====Organizations==== * {{flag|NATO}} – The [[Secretary General of NATO|Secretary General]] described the launch as a "provocative act" which "exacerbates tensions in the region and risks further destabilising the Korean peninsula".{{cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2012/12/12/uk-korea-north-nato-idUKBRE8BB0EJ20121212|title=NATO calls North Korea rocket launch "provocative"|accessdate=12 December 2012|date=12 December 2012|work=Reuters}} * {{flag|United Nations}} – The [[Secretary-General of the United Nations|Secretary-General]] [[Ban Ki-moon]] condemned the launch as a violation of [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 1874]] by conducting a launch using ballistic missile technology.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-20690762 |title=North Korea rocket: International reaction |publisher=BBC |date=12 December 2012 |accessdate=12 December 2012}} ===Registration=== On 22 February 2013, the Permanent Mission of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea to the United Nations registered the satellite in conformity with the [[Convention on Registration of Objects Launched into Outer Space]].{{cite report |author=Permanent Mission of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea to the United Nations |date=24 January 2013 |title=Information furnished in conformity with the Convention on Registration of Objects Launched into Outer Space: Note verbale dated 22 January 2013 from the Permanent Mission of the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea to the United Nations (Vienna) addressed to the Secretary-General |url=http://www.unoosa.org/pdf/reports/regdocs/ser662E.pdf |format=[[PDF]] |publisher=[[United Nations Office for Outer Space Affairs]] |accessdate=7 January 2016}} In the registration, North Korea states that the function is to survey crops, forest resources and natural disasters. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://n2yo.com/?s=39026 Live time satellite tracking] {{North Korean Space Program}} {{Orbital launches in 2012}} {{Portal bar|North Korea|Spaceflight}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kwangmyongsong-3 Unit 2}} [[Category:2012 in North Korea]] [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 2012]] [[Category:Earth observation satellites]] [[Category:Space program of North Korea]] [[Category:First artificial satellite of a country]] [[Category:Derelict satellites orbiting Earth]]

page.title: List of European regions with alternative names

revision.text:
Most '''regions and provinces of Europe''' have '''alternative names''' in different languages. Some regions have also undergone [[Geographical renaming|name changes]] for political or other reasons. This article attempts to give all known alternative names for all major European regions, provinces, and territories. It also includes some lesser regions that are important because of their location or history. This article does not offer any opinion about what the "original", "official", "real", or "correct" name of any region is or was. Regions are (mostly) listed alphabetically by their '''current best-known name in English''', which does not necessarily match the title of the corresponding article. The English version is followed by variants in other languages, in alphabetical order by name, and then by any historical variants and former names. Foreign names that are the same as their English equivalents may be listed. {{compact ToC|side=yes}} ==A== {| class="wikitable" ! English name ! Other names or former names |- | [[Aargau]] | '''Aargau''' (Turkish), '''Aargou''' (Swiss German), '''Argau''' - ''Аргау'' (Macedonian), '''Argobia''' (Aragonese), '''Argovia''' (Franco-Provençal, Galician, Italian, Latin, Romanian, Romansh, Sicilian, Spanish, variant in English), '''Argòvia''' (Catalan, Occitan), '''Argóvia''' (Portuguese), '''Argovie''' (French), '''Argovio''' (Esperanto), '''Argovja''' (Maltese), '''Argowia''' (Polish) |- | [[Abruzzo]] | '''Abbruzzu''' (Sicilian), '''Abruç''' (Occitan), '''Abrucai''' (Lithuanian), '''Abruco''' (Latvian), '''Abruco''' - ''Абруцо'' (Macedonian), '''Abruços''' (Catalan), '''Abruss''' (Piedmontese), '''Abrútsi''' (Icelandic), '''Abruz''' (Breton), '''Abruzes''' (Franco-Provençal), '''Abruzja''' (Polish), '''Abruzo''' (Esperanto), '''Abruzos''' (Aragonese, Portuguese, Spanish), '''Abruzso''' (Venetian), '''Abruzzen''' (Dutch, German), '''Abruzzes''' (French), '''Abruzzi''' or '''Abruzzo''' (Italian, Maltese, Romanian), '''Abruzzo''' (Turkish), '''Abruzzu''' (Corsican), '''Aprutium''' (Latin), '''Aprytion''' - ''Απρύτιον'' (Greek) |- | [[Achaea]] | '''Acaia''' (Catalan, Galician, Italian, Lombard, Portuguese), '''Acaya''' (Spanish), '''Achaea''' or '''Achaia''' (Dutch, English, Latin), '''Achaia''' (German, Swedish), '''an Acháia''' (Irish), '''Achaïe''' (French), '''Achaja''' (Polish), '''Achája''' (Slovak), '''Ahaja''' (Croatian, Slovene), '''Ahaja''' - ''Ахаја'' (Macedonian), '''Ahaya''' (Turkish), '''Aĥeo''' (Esperanto), '''Akaja''' (Maltese),'''Akhaia''' (Finnish, Bokmål Norwegian, Winaray), '''Akhaía''' (Nynorsk Norwegian), '''Akhaïa''' - ''Αχαΐα'' (Greek), '''Akhaya''' (Indonesian), '''Ахайя''' (Russian), '''Ахая''' (Ukrainian) |- | [[Aetolia]] | '''an Aetóil''' (Irish), '''Aetolia''' (Latin, Welsh), '''Aetolië''' (Dutch), '''Aitolía''' - ''Αιτωλία'' (Greek), '''Aitolia''' (Indonesian, Norwegian), '''Aitólia''' (Slovak), '''Aitólie''' (Czech), '''Aitolien''' (Swedish), '''Ätolien''' (German), '''Etolia''' (Basque, Italian, Polish, Spanish), '''Etólia''' (Portuguese), '''Etòlia''' (Catalan), '''Étolie''' (French), '''Etolija''' (Croatian, Lithuanian, Slovene), '''Etolija''' - ''Етолија'' (Macedonian), '''Etolja''' (Maltese), '''Etolya''' (Turkish), '''Етолия''' (Bulgarian), '''Этолия''' (Russian), '''أيتوليا''' (Arabic), '''Էտոլիա''' (Armenian) |- | [[Åland]] | '''Ahvenamaa''' (Estonian), '''Ahvenanmaa''' (Finnish), '''Aland''' (Basque, Maltese, Wolof), '''Åland''' (French, Italian, Swedish, Turkish) '''Åland''' or '''Ålandsøerne''' (Danish), '''Àland''' (Catalan), '''Áland''' (Faroese), '''Ålánda''' (Northern Sami), '''Alandai''' (Lithuanian), '''Alandia''' (Latin, Spanish), '''Alândia''' (Portuguese), '''Ålandinseln''' (German), '''Alando''' (Esperanto, Ido), '''Ålandseilanden''' (Dutch, Dutch Low Saxon), '''Álandseyjar''' or '''Áland''' (Icelandic), '''Ālandu salas''' (Latvian), '''Ålandy''' (Czech, Slovak), '''Oileáin Åland''' (Irish), '''Oland''' - ''Оланд'' or '''Olandski ostrovi''' - ''Оландски острови'' (Macedonian), '''Wyspy Alandzkie''' (Polish) |- | [[Algarve]] | '''Algarvia''' (Latin), '''Algarve''' (French, Italian, Latvian, Maltese, Portuguese, Spanish, Turkish), '''Algarve''' - ''Алгарве'' (Macedonian), '''an Algarve''' (Irish), '''Algarvė''' (Lithuanian), '''الغرب''' (Arabic) |- | [[Allgäu]] | '''Algoj''' - ''Алгој'' (Macedonian), '''Algovia''' (Italian, Latin, Romanian, Spanish), '''Algòvia''' (Catalan), '''Algovja''' (Maltese) '''Allgäu''' (Dutch, French, German, Hungarian, Portuguese, Turkish) |- | [[Alsace]] | '''Alisatia''' or '''Alsatia''' (Latin), '''Alsace''' (Danish, Estonian, French), '''Alsace''' or '''Alsass''' (Swedish), '''Alsàcia''' (Catalan), '''Alsácia''' (Portuguese), '''Alsacia''' (Romanian, Spanish), '''an Alsáis''' (Irish), '''Alsas''' or '''Alzas''' (Turkish), '''Alsasko''' (Czech), '''Alsatía''' - ''Αλσατία'' (Greek), '''Alsazia''' (Italian), '''Alsazja''' (Maltese), '''Alzacija''' (Slovene), '''Alzacja''' (Polish), '''Alzas''' - ''Алзас'' or '''Elzas''' - ''Елзас'' (Macedonian, Serbian), '''Elsass''' (Estonian alternate, Finnish, German, Alsatian, variant in Danish and Swedish), '''Elsaß''' (German, before 1996), '''Elzas''' (Afrikaans, Breton, Croatian, Dutch), '''Elzasa''' (Latvian), '''Elzasas''' (Lithuanian), '''Elzász''' (Hungarian) |- | [[Andalusia]] | '''Andalousie''' (French), '''Andalucía''' (Spanish), '''an Andalúis''' (Irish), '''Andalusia''' (Catalan, Finnish, Italian, variant in Romanian), '''Andalusija''' (Maltese), '''Andaloezië''' or '''Andalusië''' (Dutch), '''Al-Andalus''' - الأندلس (Arabic, meaning the whole Spain), '''Andalusie''' (Czech), '''Andalusien''' (Danish, German, Swedish), '''Andaluusia''' (Estonian), '''Andaluzia''' (Portuguese, Romanian), '''Andalúzia''' (Hungarian), '''Andaluzie''' (Czech), '''Andalūzija''' (Latvian, Lithuanian), '''Andaluzija''' (Slovene), '''Andaluzija''' - ''Андалузија'' (Macedonian, Serbian), '''Andaluzja''' (Polish), '''Endülüs''' (Turkish), '''Vandalitia''' (Latin), '''Vandalysia''' - ''Βανδαλυσία'' (Greek) |- | [[Ångermanland]] | '''Angermània''' (Catalan), '''Angermânia''' (Portuguese), '''Ångermanland''' (Estonian, Swedish, Turkish), '''Angermannia''' (Latin), '''Ongermanland''' - ''Онгерманланд'' or '''Angermanija''' - ''Ангерманија'' (Macedonian) |- | [[Angria]] | '''Angaria''' (English), '''Angria''' (Turkish), '''Angrie''' (French), '''Angrija''' - ''Ангрија'' (Macedonian), '''Engern''' (German), '''Aggria''' - Αγγρία (Greek) |- | [[Anhalt]] | '''Anhalt''' (Catalan, Croatian, Danish, Dutch, Estonian, French, Frisian, German, Hungarian, Italian, Low Saxon, Maltese, Norwegian, Polish, Portuguese, Romanian, Slovene, Spanish, Swedish, Turkish), '''Anhalt''' - ''Анхалт'' (Macedonian), '''Anhaltas''' (Lithuanian), '''Anhaltinum''' (Latin), '''Anhaltsko''' (Czech), '''Anholt''' (Afrikaans) |- | [[Anjou]] | '''Andegavensis''' or '''Andegavia''' (Latin), '''Andegawenia''' (Polish), '''Anjou''' (Catalan, Dutch, Estonian, French, German, Hungarian, Portuguese, Romanian, Turkish), '''Angiò''' (Italian), '''Anġò''' (Maltese), '''Anžu''' - revision.text:
{{no footnotes|date=October 2018}} [[File:Lucien Gallois.jpg|thumb|
Lucien Gallois
(before 1929)]] '''Lucien Louis Joseph Gallois''' (21 February 1857 – 21 March 1941) was a French [[geographer]] born in [[Metz]]. He was a student at the [[École Normale Supérieure]] in Paris, where he took classes from [[Paul Vidal de la Blache]] (1845–1918). In 1884 he received his [[agrégation]], later becoming a lecturer at the [[University of Paris|Sorbonne]] (1893). From 1898 to 1907 he was a professor of [[geography]] at the École Normale Supérieure, and afterwards a professor at the Sorbonne, where he remained until his retirement in 1927. Gallois made major contributions to the ''[[Annales de géographie]]'', a geographical journal that he co-founded with his mentor, Paul Vidal de la Blache. Following the death of Vidal de la Blache in 1918, he assumed directorship of ''Géographie universelle'', a major project involving [[regional geography]] of the entire world. Gallois had a keen interest in the fields of [[cartography]] and [[history of geography]], as made evident by an influential 1890 study on German geographers of the [[Renaissance]] titled ''Les géographes allemands de la Renaissance''. Another noted publication of his was ''Régions naturelles et noms de pays: Étude sur la région Parisienne'' (Natural regions and country names: A study of the Paris region). == References == {{Reflist|30em}} * "This article is based on a translation of an equivalent article at the [[French Wikipedia]]". {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gallois, Lucien}} [[Category:French geographers]] [[Category:People from Metz]] [[Category:1857 births]] [[Category:1941 deaths]] [[Category:University of Paris faculty]] [[Category:École Normale Supérieure alumni]] [[Category:École Normale Supérieure faculty]] [[Category:Recipients of the Cullum Geographical Medal]]

page.title: Parque Natural Obô de São Tomé

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
{{for|the protected area on Príncipe island|Parque Natural Obô do Príncipe}} {{Infobox protected area | name = Parque Natural Obô de São Tomé | photo = 2012SaoTome-470.jpg | photo_width = 180 | photo_caption = Pico Cão Grande | map = Sao Tome and Principe |relief = yes | map_width = 180 | map_caption = Location in São Tomé and Príncipe | alt_name = | area_km2 = 195 | iucn_category = | created = 2006 | coordinates = {{coord|0|13|N|6|34|E|type:landmark|display=it}} }} '''The Obô Natural Park of São Tomé''' ({{lang-pt|Parque Natural Obô de São Tomé}}) is a natural park of [[São Tomé and Príncipe]], covering {{convert|195|km2|abbr=on}} of the island of [[São Tomé Island|São Tomé]].<ref name="ST">{{cite web|url=https://arleciosoares13.wordpress.com/areas-protegidas/parque-natural-de-sao-tome/|title=Parque Natural d'Obô em São Tomé|accessdate=19 October 2018}}</ref> It was established in 2006.<ref>[https://arleciosoares13.files.wordpress.com/2013/10/lei-06-06-parque-natural-de-sao-tome.pdf Lei 06/2006], 13 June 2006</ref> It has not yet been assigned to a [[IUCN protected area categories|IUCN protected area category]].<ref name="dopa">{{cite web|url=https://dopa-explorer.jrc.ec.europa.eu/wdpa/124355 |title=DOPA: Parque Natural Obô de São Tomé|publisher=[[Joint Research Centre]]|accessdate=1 November 2018}}</ref><ref name="pp">{{cite web|url=https://www.protectedplanet.net/124355 |title=Parque Natural Obô de São Tomé|publisher=[[World Database on Protected Areas]]|accessdate=1 November 2018}}</ref> It covers parts of the districts of [[Caué District|Caué]], [[Lemba District|Lemba]], [[Lobata District|Lobata]] and [[Mé-Zóchi District|Mé-Zóchi]].<ref>[https://www.ine.st/index.php/publicacoes/documentos/file/178-3-caract-fisico-geograficas-5 Map of São Tomé and Príncipe], [[Instituto Nacional de Estatística (São Tomé and Príncipe)|Instituto Nacional de Estatística]]</ref>
==Geography==
The Natural Park covers three geographically separated zones:<ref name="ST"/> *the largest part is the central massif, including the mountains [[Pico de São Tomé]] and [[Pico Cão Grande]] *the zone of [[Vila Malanza|Malanza]], in the south of the island *the zone of [[Praia das Conchas, São Tomé and Príncipe|Praia das Conchas]] and [[Lagoa Azul]], in the north of the island [[File:Óbo (4238094175).jpg|thumb|right|A typical forest landscape of the park area]]
The park is known internationally amongst conservationists for its biologically rich dense virgin rainforests. It is also characterized by a wide range of [[biotope]]s, from lowland and mountain forests, to [[mangrove]]s and [[savanna]] area, which contribute to its unique ecosystem. The park includes virgin Atlantic high altitude rainforest and secondary rainforest (known to locals as ''capoeira'') which contains abandoned plantations.<ref name="Obo">{{cite web|url=http://www.obopark.com/en/saotomeprincipe/nationalparks/conservation.html|title=Conservation history|publisher=Obo Park.com|accessdate=10 November 2011|dead-url=yes|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120301171342/http://www.obopark.com/en/saotomeprincipe/nationalparks/conservation.html#|archive-date=2012-03-01|df=}}</ref>
In 1988, scientists classified the forests of São Tomé and Príncipe as the second most important in terms of biological interest out of 75 forests of Africa; most of the species found in the islands are found in the national park.<ref name="Obo"/> The [[World Wide Fund for Nature|WWF]] has listed the forests of the national park as among the [[Global 200]], the 200 most important biological areas on the planet.<ref>[http://www.biodiversitya-z.org/content/sao-tome-and-principe Sao Tome and Principe], biodiversitya-z.org</ref> The forest of Obo is listed as an [[Important Bird Area]] (IBA) of Africa.<ref name="Obo"/>
==Flora and fauna== There are about 700 plant species on the island of São Tomé,<ref name="saotomeislands.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.saotomeislands.com/naturalhistory.html|title=Natural History |publisher=Sao Tome and Principe Travel and Tourism|accessdate=1 November 2018}}</ref> of which 95 [[endemism|endemic]].<ref name=wwf>[https://www.worldwildlife.org/ecoregions/at0127 Islands of São Tomé and Príncipe of the coast of Equatorial Guinea], [[World Wildlife Fund]]</ref> Flora includes the evergreen coniferous ''[[Afrocarpus mannii]]''. Orchids, ferns and mosses are common in the area.
There are 16 endemic bird species on the island, including [[São Tomé olive pigeon]] (''Columba thomensis''), [[São Tomé ibis]] (''Bostrychia bocagei''), [[São Tomé fiscal]] (''Lanius newtoni''), [[São Tomé shorttail]] (''Amaurocichlia bocagei''),<ref name=wwf/> [[São Tomé grosbeak]] (''Crithagra concolor''), [[Giant sunbird]] (''Dreptes thomensis''), [[São Tomé oriole]] (''Oriolus crassirostris'') and [[São Tomé thrush]] (''Turdus olivaceofuscus'').<ref name="dopa" /> The amphibians ''[[Ptychadena newtoni]]'', ''[[Hyperolius thomensis]]'', ''[[Hyperolius molleri]]'', ''[[Phrynobatrachus leveleve]]'', and ''[[Schistometopum thomense]]'' are found in the park.<ref name="dopa" /> The shrew ''[[Crocidura thomensis]]'' is the only endemic terrestrial mammal. There are three endemic species of bats: [[São Tomé collared fruit bat]] (''Myonycteris brachycephala''), [[São Tomé free-tailed bat]] (''Chaerephon tomensis''),<ref name=wwf/> and [[São Tomé leaf-nosed bat]] (''Hipposideros thomensis'').<ref name="dopa" /> Invertebrates include the moths ''[[Theretra viridis]]'', ''[[Hyalobathra barnsalis]]'' and ''[[Pseudoclanis tomensis]]'' and the ant ''[[Tetramorium renae]]''.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{Commonscat|Obo National Park}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20111114193733/http://www.obopark.com/ Official site] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vNC2Dmc1ukY Video walking through the virgin rainforest] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T5vuCDocGEg Video of the secondary forest]
{{São Tomé and Príncipe topics}}
[[Category:National parks of São Tomé and Príncipe]] [[Category:São Tomé Island]] [[Category:2006 establishments in São Tomé and Príncipe]]
